Abstract
The HNC approximation for a solution of charged hard spheres is applied as a model of highly unsymmetrical electrolytes such as spherical polyelectrolytes and micelles.

France Received 26 July 1977 The HNC approximation for a solution of charged hard spheres is applied as a model of highly unsymmetrical electro- lytes such as spherical polyelectrolytes and micelles. I. Introduction The approach of macroscopic thermodynamical and transport properties of complex systems by numerical methods of statistical mechanics is considerably sim- plified by the consideration of limiting physical mod- els. For charged systems, the two most interesting limiting models are the infinite line with a uniform or periodical charge density and the uniformly charged sphere. The former can be considered as the schematic representation of linear polyelectrolytes such as poly- sacchaddes and DNA, the latter as a crude draft for globular polyelectrolytes (coil form), micelles and even as a first approximation for some particular living cells such as blood cells and some bacteria. What results from the high charge density in both linear and spherical cases is that even for the lowest concentrations the ideal behaviour and also the Debye Huckel limiting laws cannot represent the actual ex- perimental properties of such systems. In the linear case, more adequate limiting laws were derived by Manning [1] for both thermodynamical and transport properties. The case of large highly charged particles presents particular properties coming from the great dissymme- try between the large particles and the small surround- ing counterions. The electrostatic part of the interac- tion can never be separated from the geometrical part, since for a given charged large particle the strength of the coulombic interaction at its surface will depend directly on its radius. It is therefore understandable that the range of validity of the Debye Hiickel limit- ing law will be too far from concentrations of practi- cal interest. In this paper we study the thermodynamics and structure of dissymmetric model systems consisting of highly charged hard spheres and surrounding counter- ions in the framework of the HNC approximation which has proved to be very successful in the study of coulombic systems: electrolytes [2], molten salts [3] and the classical one and two component ionic plas- mas [4,5]. 2. Conclusion The application of the HNC approximation to high- ly dissymmetric ionic systems permits one to obtain the thermodynamical and structural properties in the concentration range of aqueous solutions. The studied system (anion of charge 6 and monovalent cations) could be a model for some polyphosphates or analo- gous solutions. The extension of this work to more un- symmetrical electrolytes should permit the study of a great variety of systems of physical interest, including globular polyelectrolytes and micelles.
